title.narrative: A culture and platform for dialogue and mutual understanding across geographical, ideological and other divides is established among youth in Jordan, Egypt, Tunisia and Denmark

description.narrative: In a region characterized by increased polarization and endangered by potential and unfolding conflicts, the need to promote dialogue and enhance mutual understanding between youth across ethnic, religious, political, ideological and other divides – including as a precondition for sustainable and meaningful reform and democratization processes – is apparent, paramount and growing. Since DUF’s Ambassadors for Dialogue programme is designed and intended to meet just that need, DUF has scaled up the programme in Jordan and Egypt, where local teams of 'ambassadors for dialogue' – in cooperation and partnerships with local youth organisations, networks, initiatives and institutions – implement dialogue activities for youth in order to: A) foster a dialogical culture among youth, and B) enhance mutual understanding between youth across ethnic, religious, ideological and other divides in their respective countries.

title.narrative: A culture and platform for dialogue and mutual understanding across geographical, ideological and other divides is established among youth in Jordan, Egypt, Tunisia and Denmark

description.narrative: In a region characterized by increased polarization and endangered by potential and unfolding conflicts, the need to promote dialogue and enhance mutual understanding between youth across ethnic, religious, political, ideological and other divides – including as a precondition for sustainable and meaningful reform and democratization processes – is apparent, paramount and growing. Since DUF’s Ambassadors for Dialogue programme is designed and intended to meet just that need, DUF has scaled up the programme in Jordan and Egypt, where local teams of 'ambassadors for dialogue' – in cooperation and partnerships with local youth organisations, networks, initiatives and institutions – implement dialogue activities for youth in order to: A) foster a dialogical culture among youth, and B) enhance mutual understanding between youth across ethnic, religious, ideological and other divides in their respective countries.

comment.narrative: The Jordanian, Egyptian and Tunisian societies are to different extents in danger of conflicts and are characterized by polarization and lack of mutual understanding among youth across geographical, ideological and other divides. Multi-party dialogue and cooperation is not taking place and the building of trust in democratic institutions and procedures risks being undermined by increasing sectarianism and ideological segmentation. Meanwhile, lack of knowledge and negative stereotypes about youth in the MENA region remains abundant among Danish youth and vice versa.

title.narrative: Youth organizations in Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan and Palestine improve the role and rights of young women

description.narrative: It is an on-going challenge to support and promote equal participation and opportunities of young men and women in projects carried out by Danish youth organisations supported by DUF. DUF has chosen to address this challenge in two ways. Firstly, to offer guidance and training on how to work with gender related issues, for instance how to conduct gender analysis of context and projects. Secondly, to demand that all project applications have taken into consideration how young men and women will have the opportunity to contribute and exert genuine influence on all aspects of the partnership and the intervention. Hence, all project applications are evaluated specifically with regards to their approach to gender.

title.narrative: Youth organizations in Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan and Palestine improve the role and rights of young women

description.narrative: It is an on-going challenge to support and promote equal participation and opportunities of young men and women in projects carried out by Danish youth organisations supported by DUF. DUF has chosen to address this challenge in two ways. Firstly, to offer guidance and training on how to work with gender related issues, for instance how to conduct gender analysis of context and projects. Secondly, to demand that all project applications have taken into consideration how young men and women will have the opportunity to contribute and exert genuine influence on all aspects of the partnership and the intervention. Hence, all project applications are evaluated specifically with regards to their approach to gender.

title.narrative: Youth organizations in Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan and Palestine have increased capacity in and/or practical experience with influencing own societies and contributing to reform and democratization processes

description.narrative:
This key outcome indicator (described in title) relates to the DAPP intermediate objective: 1.3 Strengthening young people’s participation in public life. This outcome is regionally targeted. The means of verification are project completion reports and interviews with DUFs members organizations and their partners, partly at DUFs obligatory evaluation seminars (two per year), and partly during monitoring visits.
Capacity building for advocacy is defined by the following activities: a) Impact duty bearers in own organization b) Train members/volunteers in advocacy c) Strategy process in the organization with the aim of increased impact on society.

title.narrative: Youth organizations in Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan and Palestine have increased capacity in and/or practical experience with influencing own societies and contributing to reform and democratization processes

description.narrative:
This key outcome indicator (described in title) relates to the DAPP intermediate objective: 1.3 Strengthening young people’s participation in public life. This outcome is regionally targeted. The means of verification are project completion reports and interviews with DUFs members organizations and their partners, partly at DUFs obligatory evaluation seminars (two per year), and partly during monitoring visits.
Capacity building for advocacy is defined by the following activities: a) Impact duty bearers in own organization b) Train members/volunteers in advocacy c) Strategy process in the organization with the aim of increased impact on society.

comment.narrative: DUFs member organizations and their partners have good experience with influencing their own societies by mobilizing youth and developing young leaders. However, none of the youth organizations have long or extensive experience with working strategically with influencing external duty bearers trough advocacy. Some have started out by small actual advocacy activities while others have started building awareness internally within the organizations on the importance of working with advocacy as an element in their project strategy, but have not yet done actual advocacy activities. At the end of 2014 six MENA organizations work with capacity building for advocacy. Two organizations have had external advocacy activities in 2014. Five MENA organizations did not have any advocacy work in their projects. Status, September 2015: Ten MENA organisations are in a process of training members or staff for advocacy activities or are actually engaged in advocacy.

title.narrative: 1. A strengthened civil society and democratic political culture in the MENA-region where youth are organised and youth organisations have influence.

description.narrative: Youth organisations in Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan and Palestine have increased capacity in and/or practical experience with influencing own societies and contributing to reform and democratization processes

comment.narrative:
DUFs member organisations and their partners have good experience with influencing their own societies by mobilizing youth and developing young leaders. However, none of the youth organisations have long or extensive experience with working strategically with influencing external duty bearers trough advocacy. Some have started out by small actual advocacy activities while others have started building awareness internally within their partnerships on the importance of working with advocacy as an element in their projects, but have not yet done actual advocacy activities.
At the end of 2014 six MENA organisations work with capacity building for advocacy. Two organisations have had external advocacy activities in 2014. Five MENA organisations did not have any advocacy work in their projects.
